oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington’s speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington.
oai_dc:dc.dc:provenance: Provenance Transfer; Manuscript Division (Booker T. Washington papers); 1973 (DLC/PP-1973:148), 1995 (DLC/PP-1995:013).
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Additional form available Digitized images of some items in the collection and their associated identifying information are available through the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, by searching using the call number, "LOT 13164."

Surrogates Six original film negatives are stored offsite under the filing series designation LC-W2723-1 through LC-W2723-6. One glass lantern slide is stored under the filing designation LC-W2733-1. Surrogates for these images in the form of color laser photocopies have been interfiled within the LOT. The LOT also includes original damaged photoprints which have been reformatted as digital surrogates for access purposes. These digitized images were printed and have been interfiled within the LOT for reference purposes. The original damaged photographs cannot be served.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Collection Summary Visual materials from the Booker T. Washington papers 1889-1935bulk 1897-1915 LOT 13164 701 items (chiefly photographic prints); 57 x 41 cm. or smaller. Prints & Photographs Division Library of Congress Washington, D.C. Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington’s speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington. For information about Prints and Photographs Division collections and services, see the Prints & Photographs Division's Reading Room Home Page. Collection material in English Selected Search Terms The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein. People Bedou, A. P. (Arthur P.), 1882-1966, photographer. Johnston, Frances Benjamin, 1864-1952, photographer. Washington, Booker T., 1856-1915, collector. Washington, Booker T., 1856-1915. Organizations Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute--1880-1940. Subjects African Americans--1880-1940. Buildings--1880-1940. Educational facilities--United States--1880-1940. Floats (Parades)--Alabama--Tuskegee--1900-1910. Public speaking--1900-1920. School children--1880-1940. Schools--United States--1890-1940. Students--1890-1940. Universities & colleges--United States--1890-1940. Women--Education--United States--1880-1940. Women--Education--United States--1880-1940. Form/Genre Albumen prints--1880-1920. Gelatin silver prints--1890-1940. Group portraits--1880-1940. Photomechanical prints--1890-1940. Portraits--1880-1940. Administrative Information Provenance Transfer; Manuscript Division (Booker T. Washington papers); 1973 (DLC/PP-1973:148), 1995 (DLC/PP-1995:013). Restrictions No known donor restrictions. Rights status of individual images not evaluated. For more information see reference aid: Copyright and Other Restrictions Which Apply to Publication and Other Forms of Distribution of Images: Sources of Information. Additional form available Digitized images of some items in the collection and their associated identifying information are available through the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, by searching using the call number, "LOT 13164." Surrogates Six original film negatives are stored offsite under the filing series designation LC-W2723-1 through LC-W2723-6. One glass lantern slide is stored under the filing designation LC-W2733-1. Surrogates for these images in the form of color laser photocopies have been interfiled within the LOT. The LOT also includes original damaged photoprints which have been reformatted as digital surrogates for access purposes. These digitized images were printed and have been interfiled within the LOT for reference purposes. The original damaged photographs cannot be served. Preferred Citation Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: LOT 13164, Visual Materials from the Booker T. Washington Papers, Prints & Photographs Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. Biographical Note Booker T. Washington was born into slavery in 1856 and after Emancipation grew up in the Kanawha Valley of West Va. At the age of 16 he enrolled in the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, Va. In 1881, on the recommendation of staff of the Hampton Institute, he was hired to found a school for African Americans in Tuskegee, Ala. Booker T. Washington became a prominent leader as the result of his fund-raising efforts for Tuskegee. By 1895, Washington had a reputation as a public speaker which is reflected in this collection. He gained the respect of Theodore Roosevelt, who became a trustee of Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute in 1910. Washington died at Tuskegee on November 14, 1915 shortly after a speaking engagement in the Northeast. Scope and Content Note Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington's speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington. Organization of the Papers Arranged by subject and size into twelve sub-groups as follows: Booker T. Washington portraits and memorials (LOT 13164-A); Washington at public speaking engagements (LOT 13164-B); Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute (LOT 13164-C); Portraits (LOT 13164-D and LOT 13164-E); Colleges & Universities (LOT 13164-F); Canning & Poultry Club Conference, Caroline Co., Va., Aug. 8, 1913 (LOT 13164-G); YMCA buildings and facilities (LOT 13164-H); Identified and unidentified buildings (LOT 13164-I and LOT 13164-J); Agricultural workers (LOT 13164-K); Miscellaneous (LOT 13164-L). http://lccn.loc.gov/99472031 Overview of Collection Arrangement and Content Contents Call No. Portraits, statues, and memorials of Booker T. Washington and his family ca. 1890-1935 LOT 13164-A Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Also includes group portraits of Washington family members; a reproduction of a landscape painting by Mrs. Frank R. Hill entitled "Mt. Booker Washington," (1904); a design for a memorial portrait group designed and copyrighted by photographer C.M. Battey (c1911); one portrait of Margaret Murray Washington. Washington at public speaking engagements ca. 1900-1914 LOT 13164-B Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Includes Washington addressing large crowds at locations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia as well as other unidentified locations. Also views of crowds gathered at the various venues; Washington traveling by coach, automobile, and train to locations; some group portraits, including one of Washington posing with Mary McCloud Bethune. Arranged alphabetically by city. Tuskegee Institute 1890-1910 LOT 13164-C Box 2 (F size), Box 6 (H size), and Box 8 (OH size) Includes campus views of buildings and monuments, student portraits, campus events, including a celebration and parade for President Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 and a 25th anniversary ceremony. Also includes portraits of faculty and alumni; students attending classes. Portraits of Washington's associates ca. 1889-1914 LOT 13164-D Box 3 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) All are F size unless otherwise noted. Includes single and group portraits. Arranged alphabetically by sitter's surname. Unidentified portraits ca. 1890-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-E Box 4 (F size) and Box 7 (H size) Includes men, women, and children. Also group portraits. Colleges and schools (excluding Tuskegee) ca. 1900-1916 LOT 13164-F Boxes 5 (F size) and Box 7 (H size) Includes public schools and colleges primarily in the South; school buildings and group portraits of students standing in front of school buildings; campus views; students attending classes. Also two portraits of Hawaiian school children; one portrait of Japanese school children. Arranged alphabetically by school name. Canning & Poultry Club Conference, Caroline Co. Aug. 8, 1913 LOT 13164-G Box 5 (F size) YMCA 1912-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-H Box 5 (F size) Includes buildings and activities at YMCA facilities in Arundel-on-the-Bay, Md., Bexton, Iowa, Chicago, Ill., Columbus, Ga., Indianapolis, Ind., Philadelphia, Washington, D.C. Arranged alphabetically by city. Buildings ca. 1900-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-I Box 5 (F size) Residences, commercial buildings, and churches. Includes the Frederick Douglass home in Anacostia, Washington, D.C. Includes views in Alabama, Florida, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Tennessee, and Virginia. Arranged alphabetically by city. Unidentified buildings ca. 1900-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-J Box 5 (F size) Exterior views of dwellings and commercial buildings. Agricultural workers ca. 1905-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-K Box 5 (F size) Children and adults working or posing in gardens. One group portrait of two aged women posing in front of a tent. Miscellaneous subjects ca. 1900-ca. 1910 LOT 13164-L Box 5 (F size) Includes city views, some buildings, people at unidentified events, other unidentified subjects. One unidentified color waterfront view; one praline candy box with a portrait of two women. Washington portraits and memorials (LOT 13164-A); Washington at public speaking engagements (LOT 13164-B); Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute (LOT 13164-C); Portraits (LOT 13164-D and LOT 13164-E); Colleges & Universities (LOT 13164-F); Canning & Poultry Club Conference, Caroline Co., Va., Aug. 8, 1913 (LOT 13164-G); YMCA buildings and facilities (LOT 13164-H); Identified and unidentified buildings (LOT 13164-I and LOT 13164-J); Agricultural workers (LOT 13164-K); Miscellaneous (LOT 13164-L).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Biographical Note Booker T. Washington was born into slavery in 1856 and after Emancipation grew up in the Kanawha Valley of West Va. At the age of 16 he enrolled in the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, Va. In 1881, on the recommendation of staff of the Hampton Institute, he was hired to found a school for African Americans in Tuskegee, Ala. Booker T. Washington became a prominent leader as the result of his fund-raising efforts for Tuskegee. By 1895, Washington had a reputation as a public speaker which is reflected in this collection. He gained the respect of Theodore Roosevelt, who became a trustee of Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute in 1910. Washington died at Tuskegee on November 14, 1915 shortly after a speaking engagement in the Northeast.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Portraits, statues, and memorials of Booker T. Washington and his family ca. 1890-1935 LOT 13164-A Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Also includes group portraits of Washington family members; a reproduction of a landscape painting by Mrs. Frank R. Hill entitled "Mt. Booker Washington," (1904); a design for a memorial portrait group designed and copyrighted by photographer C.M. Battey (c1911); one portrait of Margaret Murray Washington.

Washington at public speaking engagements ca. 1900-1914 LOT 13164-B Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Includes Washington addressing large crowds at locations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia as well as other unidentified locations. Also views of crowds gathered at the various venues; Washington traveling by coach, automobile, and train to locations; some group portraits, including one of Washington posing with Mary McCloud Bethune. Arranged alphabetically by city.

Tuskegee Institute 1890-1910 LOT 13164-C Box 2 (F size), Box 6 (H size), and Box 8 (OH size) Includes campus views of buildings and monuments, student portraits, campus events, including a celebration and parade for President Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 and a 25th anniversary ceremony. Also includes portraits of faculty and alumni; students attending classes.

Portraits of Washington's associates ca. 1889-1914 LOT 13164-D Box 3 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) All are F size unless otherwise noted. Includes single and group portraits. Colleges and schools (excluding Tuskegee) ca. 1900-1916 LOT 13164-F Boxes 5 (F size) and Box 7 (H size) Includes public schools and colleges primarily in the South; school buildings and group portraits of students standing in front of school buildings; campus views; students attending classes. Rights status of individual images not evaluated. For more information see reference aid: Copyright and Other Restrictions Which Apply to Publication and Other Forms of Distribution of Images: Sources of Information. Additional form available Digitized images of some items in the collection and their associated identifying information are available through the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, by searching using the call number, "LOT 13164." Surrogates Six original film negatives are stored offsite under the filing series designation LC-W2723-1 through LC-W2723-6. One glass lantern slide is stored under the filing designation LC-W2733-1. Surrogates for these images in the form of color laser photocopies have been interfiled within the LOT. The LOT also includes original damaged photoprints which have been reformatted as digital surrogates for access purposes. These digitized images were printed and have been interfiled within the LOT for reference purposes. The original damaged photographs cannot be served. Preferred Citation Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: LOT 13164, Visual Materials from the Booker T. Washington Papers, Prints & Photographs Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

Overview of Collection Arrangement and Content Contents Call No. Portraits, statues, and memorials of Booker T. Washington and his family ca. 1890-1935 LOT 13164-A Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Also includes group portraits of Washington family members; a reproduction of a landscape painting by Mrs. Frank R. Hill entitled "Mt. Booker Washington," (1904); a design for a memorial portrait group designed and copyrighted by photographer C.M. Battey (c1911); one portrait of Margaret Murray Washington. Washington at public speaking engagements ca. 1900-1914 LOT 13164-B Box 1 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) Includes Washington addressing large crowds at locations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia as well as other unidentified locations. Also views of crowds gathered at the various venues; Washington traveling by coach, automobile, and train to locations; some group portraits, including one of Washington posing with Mary McCloud Bethune. Arranged alphabetically by city. Tuskegee Institute 1890-1910 LOT 13164-C Box 2 (F size), Box 6 (H size), and Box 8 (OH size) Includes campus views of buildings and monuments, student portraits, campus events, including a celebration and parade for President Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 and a 25th anniversary ceremony. Also includes portraits of faculty and alumni; students attending classes. Portraits of Washington's associates ca. 1889-1914 LOT 13164-D Box 3 (F size) and Box 6 (H size) All are F size unless otherwise noted. Includes single and group portraits. Arranged alphabetically by sitter's surname. Altiers, Genoiro 1906Puerto Rico Amos, Moses, Dr. 1904Gate City, Georgia Arkansas Business Mens League Baldwin, William (H size) Borchers, [Edw.?] 1903 Bromet, M.S. 1904Paris Brooks, A. (H size) Lyon, Ernest (Consul-General to the Republic of Liberia), and Emmett J. Scott 1909 Marr, J. M. Moundbayou, Mississippi Martin, Isaac D. [Alabama] (2 poses) Mason, [W. G.] Maxwell, Minnie P. R. 1907Rio de Janeiro, Brazil Morris, S. L. Moton, Robert R. and James W. Johnson [after 1915] Payton, J. W. [South Carolina] Plummer, D. J. Bournemouth, England Powell, Annie M. Washington, D.C. Pratt, Lawton L. [1913] Reid, William Cooper 1903Fulton, Mississippi Roosevelt family Roosevelt, Theodore 1908 Sanghorne, Edw. T. [1910] Scott, Emmett J. (2 poses) Sheridan, James Jay 1903Chicago Simons, H. L Columbia, South Carolina Soga, A. Kirkland East London, South Africa Swann, J. Richard Tanner, Henry O. (H size) Terborg, William Surinam Terry, Matt [Toicard, C.?] 1905Haiti (2 poses) Walker, S. C. [California] Watkins, son of Lee W. Unidentified portraits ca. 1890-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-E Box 4 (F size) and Box 7 (H size) Includes men, women, and children. Also group portraits. Colleges and schools (excluding Tuskegee) ca. 1900-1916 LOT 13164-F Boxes 5 (F size) and Box 7 (H size) Includes public schools and colleges primarily in the South; school buildings and group portraits of students standing in front of school buildings; campus views; students attending classes. Also two portraits of Hawaiian school children; one portrait of Japanese school children. Arranged alphabetically by school name. Canning & Poultry Club Conference, Caroline Co. Aug. 8, 1913 LOT 13164-G Box 5 (F size) YMCA 1912-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-H Box 5 (F size) Includes buildings and activities at YMCA facilities in Arundel-on-the-Bay, Md., Bexton, Iowa, Chicago, Ill., Columbus, Ga., Indianapolis, Ind., Philadelphia, Washington, D.C. Arranged alphabetically by city. Buildings ca. 1900-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-I Box 5 (F size) Residences, commercial buildings, and churches. Includes the Frederick Douglass home in Anacostia, Washington, D.C. Includes views in Alabama, Florida, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Tennessee, and Virginia. Arranged alphabetically by city. Unidentified buildings ca. 1900-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-J Box 5 (F size) Exterior views of dwellings and commercial buildings. Agricultural workers ca. 1905-ca. 1915 LOT 13164-K Box 5 (F size) Children and adults working or posing in gardens. One group portrait of two aged women posing in front of a tent. Miscellaneous subjects ca. 1900-ca. 1910 LOT 13164-L Box 5 (F size) Includes city views, some buildings, people at unidentified events, other unidentified subjects. One unidentified color waterfront view; one praline candy box with a portrait of two women.

Collection Summary Visual materials from the Booker T. Washington papers 1889-1935bulk 1897-1915 LOT 13164 701 items (chiefly photographic prints); 57 x 41 cm. or smaller. Prints & Photographs Division Library of Congress Washington, D.C. Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington’s speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington. For information about Prints and Photographs Division collections and services, see the Prints & Photographs Division's Reading Room Home Page. Collection material in English

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: For information about Prints and Photographs Division collections and services, see the Prints & Photographs Division's Reading Room Home Page.

The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.
All are F size unless otherwise noted. Includes single and group portraits.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Prints & Photographs Division Library of Congress Washington, D.C.
Prints & Photographs Division Library of Congress Washington, D.C.

Scope and Content Note Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington's speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington.

Also includes group portraits of Washington family members; a reproduction of a landscape painting by Mrs. Frank R. Hill entitled "Mt. Booker Washington," (1904); a design for a memorial portrait group designed and copyrighted by photographer C.M. Battey (c1911); one portrait of Margaret Murray Washington.

Includes Washington addressing large crowds at locations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia as well as other unidentified locations. Also views of crowds gathered at the various venues; Washington traveling by coach, automobile, and train to locations; some group portraits, including one of Washington posing with Mary McCloud Bethune.

Includes campus views of buildings and monuments, student portraits, campus events, including a celebration and parade for President Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 and a 25th anniversary ceremony. Also includes portraits of faculty and alumni; students attending classes.
Includes men, women, and children. Also group portraits.

Includes public schools and colleges primarily in the South; school buildings and group portraits of students standing in front of school buildings; campus views; students attending classes. Also two portraits of Hawaiian school children; one portrait of Japanese school children.
Includes buildings and activities at YMCA facilities in Arundel-on-the-Bay, Md., Bexton, Iowa, Chicago, Ill., Columbus, Ga., Indianapolis, Ind., Philadelphia, Washington, D.C.

Residences, commercial buildings, and churches. Includes the Frederick Douglass home in Anacostia, Washington, D.C. Includes views in Alabama, Florida, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Tennessee, and Virginia.
Exterior views of dwellings and commercial buildings.
Children and adults working or posing in gardens. One group portrait of two aged women posing in front of a tent.
Includes city views, some buildings, people at unidentified events, other unidentified subjects. One unidentified color waterfront view; one praline candy box with a portrait of two women.

Scope and Content Note Photographs document the activities of Booker T. Washington as a leader and agrarian organizer in the South at the turn of the century. Many depict Booker T. Washington's speaking engagements at such places as Ocala, Tallahasee, and Daytona, Fla.; Mound Bayou, Miss.; and Baton Rouge, La. The collection also includes photographs that document classes and activities at the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., including a parade for the celebration of the visit of President Theodore Roosevelt on October 24, 1905; celebrations for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Institute in 1906; and students building dormitories and other facilities. Also includes a group portrait of the faculty of the Institute in 1897, as well as a few images of such faculty members as Frederick Douglass, Emmett Scott, and George Washington Carver. In addition, the collection contains portraits of other African Americans, including Blanche K. Bruce, Henry O. Tanner, John R. Lynch, Richard T. Greener, and John M. Langston, as well as alumni of Tuskegee Institute. Also includes portraits of African American students at other schools in the South. Many images are unique because of personal inscriptions to Booker T. Washington.

Also includes group portraits of Washington family members; a reproduction of a landscape painting by Mrs. Frank R. Hill entitled "Mt. Booker Washington," (1904); a design for a memorial portrait group designed and copyrighted by photographer C.M. Battey (c1911); one portrait of Margaret Murray Washington.

Includes Washington addressing large crowds at locations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia as well as other unidentified locations. Also views of crowds gathered at the various venues; Washington traveling by coach, automobile, and train to locations; some group portraits, including one of Washington posing with Mary McCloud Bethune.

Includes campus views of buildings and monuments, student portraits, campus events, including a celebration and parade for President Theodore Roosevelt in 1905 and a 25th anniversary ceremony. Also includes portraits of faculty and alumni; students attending classes.
Includes men, women, and children. Also group portraits.

Includes public schools and colleges primarily in the South; school buildings and group portraits of students standing in front of school buildings; campus views; students attending classes. Also two portraits of Hawaiian school children; one portrait of Japanese school children.
Includes buildings and activities at YMCA facilities in Arundel-on-the-Bay, Md., Bexton, Iowa, Chicago, Ill., Columbus, Ga., Indianapolis, Ind., Philadelphia, Washington, D.C.

Residences, commercial buildings, and churches. Includes the Frederick Douglass home in Anacostia, Washington, D.C. Includes views in Alabama, Florida, Kansas, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Tennessee, and Virginia.
Exterior views of dwellings and commercial buildings.
Children and adults working or posing in gardens. One group portrait of two aged women posing in front of a tent.
Includes city views, some buildings, people at unidentified events, other unidentified subjects. One unidentified color waterfront view; one praline candy box with a portrait of two women.
